content:
The section discusses the lease authorization for the Caneel Bay resort in the Virgin Islands National Park, outlining definitions and the Secretary's authority to enter into a lease agreement for the property. The Secretary may enter into a lease with the owner of the retained use estate for the operation and management of the resort, acquire associated property, and administer it as part of the Park. The lease shall be in accordance with Public Law 91-383 and be for the minimum number of years practicable. The lease for the resort must not exceed 40 years and requires approval for any transfer or sale. The resort's size and guest accommodations cannot increase, and partial ownership shares or timeshares are prohibited. The lease must protect the natural, cultural, and historic features of the resort. The lease must protect natural, cultural, and historic features, with rental amounts determined based on property value and use of proceeds available to the Secretary. The Secretary can use a lease for visitor services and resource protection in the Park without needing further appropriation. The Secretary must notify Congress 60 days before awarding a lease, and leases cannot be extended or renewed. Upon lease termination, commercial services may continue under the National Park Service Concessions Management Improvement Act. The owner of the retained use estate must transfer ownership of improvements to the National Park Service without compensation. An independent appraiser will determine the value of the relinquished term of the retained use estate.
